comments.commentBody: Perhaps if our own nation's Republican partisans continue to refuse to allow a bi-partisan committee and a special prosecutor to investigate this (cyber) act of war it might be best to hand over all the evidence to the international court in The Hague?
Did these meetings use Moscow rules?

replies.commentBody: Well better it be found than hidden, as the Trump administration and the GOP are clearly trying to do. If the ultimate end of this is a crime committed by Trump and his associates, then any GOP official involved in ending this investigation is as guilty as Trump.

comments.commentBody: This process is ongoing within and outside government circles.  When it finally lands with some definite conclusions, I fear the result will be cataclysmic for the current administration.  Not that I want to defend them, but such a disastrous event just cannot be good for our country.

replies.commentBody: Seth, I think you need to read the article -- specifically the timeline, what was known when -- again.  Hopefully you will see for yourself that your theory does not fit it.

comments.commentBody: It seems likely that Obama also believed that Trump would lose the election and thereby make the need for the data irrelevant (or at least not important for election outcomes). Not sharing at the time was likely calculated by the Obama administration in order to keep a sitting president out of election meddling. Given the outcome, all that was left was to ensure that the material wouldn't be buried by the incoming administration.

I hate the way that this is all playing out, lying, cheating, slander, treason, and still nothing is done, and we are stuck with donald trump, and fearful for our Nation.  A kid does some graffiti and pays a big price, trump and the GOP get away with treason!
Thank goodness!

The never ending denials by Trump's people is an insult to all Americans. Trump has gone from bragging and rubbing the cheating and lying in our faces during his campaign to accusing everyone on the planet of being dishonest and trying to ruin "his good name and reputation".

Personally, what I'm most concerned about now in light of his dictatorial attempts is the increase in the military budget. I doubt this increase is intended to protect the country. My concern is that he will turn this into a military state and everyone and anyone who disagrees with him or his regime will pay a steep price.

Nothing he can ever say or do could instill a modicum of trust in me - or most rational people. His history of lying, breaking contracts, cheating vendors of out money they earned, bankrupting businesses and manipulating deals - not to mention not paying taxes for decades is an enormous stink bomb. And then there's the issue of him refusing to produce his tax returns has presidents have done for decades.

Obama's administration did exactly what they were supposed to do and thank God they did. I can understand why Obama did attack Trump. It's likely he could have done more damage had he engaged in an attack as an outgoing president. He played it right.

And we should keep in mind there's more going on behind the scenes that we'll ever be privy to.

Something is rotten here and it as smelled rotten since before the November election. Why the bromance between Trump and Putin? It makes no sense, there's definitely a there, there.

Let's hope we can find it before whatever it is rots completely away.
Is this the "there, there" Spicer said didn't exist? Stay tuned!

When you sup with the devil, be sure to bring a long spoon.

Molotov-Von Ribbentrop 1939; Kislyak-Flynn 2016.

The difference being of course that Germany had its "government" firmly in place and, up until 1941 and Operation Barbarossa, was operating from a position of strength, albeit a strength based on murderous insanity.

Over the next three years and 10 months Steve Bannon, Stephen Miller and the rest of the West Wing alt-right appratchiks are going to get a painful lesson in the true meaning of realpolitik.

Unfortunately, so will the rest of us. Congress must recognize that it needs to do it's job, if not for the good of the country at least to preserve itself and the institutions that make elective office and all those wonderful perks possible.

If I remember my Greek, "idios" was applied to those who had no opinion in the polis: women, children foreigners and slaves. Times have changed, thank god, but not idiots. The irony is they're largely white male men. Actually the word 'irony' doesn't begin to cover it.
Just goes to show that the swamp is now in the white house.
Thank you NYT for staying on this story!

replies.commentBody:
I see professionalism, deep love of country and a desire to protect our electoral system from future damage. How sad yet telling that they felt they incoming administration would likely not share their concerns and values.

I will never understand why Trump's supporters feel he deserves a pass on basic standards of integrity. Imagine the outcry for any other politician behaving as he and his staff have done.
It sounds to me like they did have (do have) plenty of evidence against Trump and company, but decided to give him enough rope to hang himself.

I think the Intelligence Community absolutely did the right thing in spreading this information as far as possible across the government and to our closest allies. They ensured the preservation of critical information pertinent to an attack on our country and the preservation of our democracy. How does any American NOT support those patriotic goals? Remember Trump made his disdain for the IC well known prior to the election. He knew they could bring him down. The Obama administration and the IC had a moral duty to preserve the information by any means necessary.

comments.commentBody:
This story seems to me to describe borderline treasonous actions by a group of paranoid individuals. I think they did Obama, and his legacy, a disservice. Obama rightly ordered a full review before he left office. I think the admin should have acted in good faith, in accordance with the outcome of that review. If there was evidence for real ties that then would have been communicated to all with high clearance. There would have been no way to cover it up.

Overall, seems like a Hail Mary attempt at finding a political silver bullet by dumping raw singint all over the place. It's a win-win because even if it turns up nothing, their political enemies will have the McCarthy stink on them. This seems Nixonian to me. I'm sure partisans on the left will make excuses for this, but I hope you just stop and think about the long term consequences of people in power using the power of the intelligence community as a way of punishing their political foes. Those concerned that Trump's election will lead to real damage to our institutions might be right, but at least part of that will be because he evoked the ire of people willing to corrupt the government to get back at him.

President Obama's few words on the subject are understandable; he was a politician, not an intelligence officer.
However, James Comey's silence on the Russia/Trump investigations, contrasted with his loose lips about Hillary Clinton's duplicate emails, is inexcusable.
Comey was supposed to be an intelligence officer but became a politician.

No Donald, there is no "witch-hunt" for Putin.
No Donald, our intelligence officers are not out of Nazi Germany.
No Donald, you and Putin don't have a future of collaboration for the benefit of geopolitics.
No Donald, you don't deserve our highest office.
No, Donald, you can't hide the truth forever.

replies.commentBody: It will occur at the same moment that Trump releases his tax returns.

If there's nothing to it, then Trump and co. should be able to let an independent investigation run its course. that they keep opposing it comes close to a tacit admission of guilt even as they deny it.
Mad King Donald hasn't even released, as promised, his tax returns. It's highly unlikely he will declassify anything related to this investigation.

comments.commentBody: I'm my reading of this the most important action that needs to take place is the declassifying of intelligence.  President Trump could order this to clear his name.  I doubt that will occur. It will take courage on some Republicans part to make this happen. Anything less than a full telling of this will only fuel further division. Either way, the conclusions derived must be clear and unassailable.

Regarding the intelligence we have on the connection between Russian operatives and the Trump campaign team, hark! the old saying: " if it looks like a duck, and it walks like a duck and it quacks like a duck -- it's a Donald duck!!

Trump will be impeached.
He's like an onion: the longer you peel, the more it stinks.

replies.commentBody: "The most unsettling revelation in this article is the public silence of President Obama, whose Administration".....You are forgetting that that from every available poll Clinton was going to win the election anyway. Meanwhile Trump was already complaining to his base that the election was rigged. It is only reasonable under the circumstances that the Obama Administration would be very cautious about any action or statement that would appear to be putting a thumb on the scale for Clinton.
But if Obama felt so strongly that our election was being tampered with by Russia, wouldn't that take priority over purely political concerns?

Not necessarily. Plus, I don't believe by election day that he had sufficient evidence. Remember, he ordered a report to be due in January. Then he and Trump were briefed and Obama spoke out. Notice that Trump, who was briefed, had nothing to say.

comments.commentBody:
The most unsettling revelation in this article is the public silence of President Obama, whose Administration was privately scurrying around and about to preserve critical evidence of the Trump-Russia liaison. I understand that he didn't want to in any way besmirch the incoming administration. And besides, there were still large holes in the intelligence that prompted caution.

Yet one can't help but feel that this was another -- and perhaps the quintessential -- example of Democratic reticence in the dog-eat-dog environment of Presidential politics. Republicans, with the roles reversed, would have jumped all over these revelations and accused Obama and/or Hillary Clinton of treason, or worse.

Wait! They did.

replies.commentBody: Not my president, now or ever. Get him out.

comments.commentBody: This is the stuff that James Bond movies are made of and with Trump it's business as usual?
Traitorous Trump.

This story should send a chill down the spine of every citizen of this great country.

Instead, those of us who are not republicans are having our spines chilled by the brazen actions to suppress this by the trump White House.

When some republicans in Congress finally grow a spine and vote with the Democrats to investigate this stinking mess, we might thank President Obama (again!) for the actions of his administration to preserve the evidence.

Evidence that more and more looks like it might expose acts of treason or other crimes from trump organization syndicate.
Lock him up. Lock him up. Lock him up.

replies.commentBody: They have put party above country. Tragically they are not patriots but political hacks, and worse.

comments.commentBody:
While we know there was a serious attempt to interfere in our election, we are never likely to find out the extent of that interference or whether it tilted the election to Trump. Even if Trump should some day be impeached, it would be a virtual impossibility to determine if the Russians had a critical role in changing the outcome of 2016. This is part of what makes it so upsetting because we have no mechanism in the Constitution or in common practice to set an election right if it had been fatally corrupted. We are just supposed to shut up and live with the results? Yes.

If an outside nation can steal a presidential election, anything we value can be stolen. Aside from its pile of nuclear weapons, Russia is not a powerful nation economically nor in its influence around the world. Yet, they appear to be waging war on the western nations by other means, cyber warfare.

Trump wants to make nice with the Russians. Trump says being friends with people like this is to our benefit, but there is no gain in friendship with a nation that attempts to overthrow democracy.

This should not be a Republican v. Democrat issue. Yet, there are people in power on Capitol Hill in Congress who just don't seem to care, as long as they get what they want. Are they patriots?

replies.commentBody: "I suppose we cannot assume that Trump was not involved, either in directing his "associates" or passively receiving information from them."....Do you really think that Flynn made those phone calls to the Russian ambassador entirely on his own initiative?

Not that it it will make much difference in the end but he may have contacted the ambassador on his own.  My impression of Flynn is that he considered himself to be a pezzonovante and didn't need anybody's permission.

comments.commentBody: I suppose we cannot assume that Trump was not involved, either in directing his "associates" or passively receiving information from them. Will the President be able to stymie the investigation by locking down classified information and asserting executive privilege? It seems that such a strategy would be self-defeating in that it would draw out the investigative process and increase the number of avenues followed by investigators. If the information indeed is spread far and wide among agencies then it eventually will come out.
